title: How to Make Carrot Fries

steps.headline: Heat the oil until it reaches the right temperature.
steps.description: Add 5 cups (1 l) of vegetable oil to a heavy-bottomed saucepan. Place a deep frying temperature in the pan, and heat the oil over medium heat until the temperature reaches 350 degrees Fahrenheit (177 degrees Celsius). If you don’t have a deep frying temperature, a candy thermometer will also work to monitor the oil’s temperature. If you don’t have a thermometer that can withstand high temperatures, toss a small cube of bread into the oil. The oil is hot enough if the bread browns in 3 minutes. Be careful around the hot oil. It can bubble and splatter if it gets too hot.

steps.headline: Place the egg whites and breadcrumbs in side by side bowls.
steps.description: Add 6 large, beaten egg whites to a medium bowl. Set a second medium bowl beside it, and fill it with 3 cups (270 g) of panko breadcrumbs. You can substitute regular bread crumbs for the panko if you prefer.

steps.headline: Dip the carrot sticks in the egg and toss them in the breadcrumbs.
steps.description: For the fries, you’ll need 4 large carrots that have been peeled and cut into 3-inch (8-cm) long by ½-inch (13-mm) thick sticks. Coat the sticks with the egg whites and then dip them in the breadcrumbs until they are completely covered. After you dip the carrot sticks in the egg whites, make sure to allow the excess to drip back into the bowl. Have a plate or cookie sheet lined with parchment paper ready so you place the carrot fries on it before you fry them.

steps.headline: Fry the carrot fries until they are a deep brown.
steps.description: Once the fries are coated with the breadcrumbs, add them to the hot oil in batches. Allow the carrots to fry until they become a deep brown color, which should take 3 to 4 minutes. Use a wooden spoon to move the fries around as they’re frying to ensure that they cook evenly and don’t wind up stuck together.

steps.headline: Drain the fries on a paper towel-lined plate.
steps.description: When the fries are finished frying, use a slotted spoons to carefully remove them from the oil. Place them on a plate that’s lined with paper towel to absorb the excess oil.

steps.headline: Sprinkle the fries with salt and pepper and serve.
steps.description: To plate the carrot fries, transfer them to a platter. Add some salt and pepper to taste and serve. You can serve the carrot fries with your favorite fry dipping sauce, but because the carrots are sweet, you may prefer to serve them with a spicy or tart dip, such as a chipotle ketchup or lemon yogurt dip.

methods.name: Preparing Simple Oven Baked Carrot Fries

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and grease a baking sheet.
steps.description: To ensure that the oven is hot enough to roast the carrot fries, set the temperature to 450 degrees Fahrenheit (230 degrees Celsius) and allow it to heat fully. Next, use canola oil to lightly grease a large baking sheet. You can substitute olive or vegetable oil for the canola oil.

steps.headline: Peel and cut the carrots.
steps.description: For the fries, you’ll need 1 pound (454 g) of fresh carrots. Use a vegetable peeler to remove the skin and then slice the carrots into ½-inch (13-mm) sticks with a sharp knife. You can cut the carrots into fries in any size that you like, but be aware that you may need to adjust the cooking time. Fries that are thicker than ½-inch (13-mm) will need to cook longer, while fries that are thinner will likely require less cooking time.

steps.headline: Toss the carrot fries with the oil and salt.
steps.description: Place the carrot sticks into a large bowl. Add 2 teaspoons (10 ml) of olive oil and ½ teaspoon (3 g) of kosher salt, and mix the carrots well to ensure that they’re evenly seasoned. You can add any other seasonings that you like to the fries. Black pepper, cayenne pepper, garlic powder, chili powder, and paprika are all tasty options.

steps.headline: Transfer the fries to the baking sheet and bake until crispy.
steps.description: Once the carrot fries are properly seasoned, place them on the greased baking sheet in a single layer. Set them in the oven, and allow them to cook for 10 to 12 minutes, or until they are as crisp as you’d like. The carrot fries should be crisp on the outside but still tender on the inside just like traditional potato fries.

steps.headline: Serve the fries while still warm.
steps.description: When the fries are finished cooking, remove the baking sheet from the oven. Transfer them to a plate or platter, and serve while they are still warm. While the carrot fries are delicious on their own, you can also serve them with a dipping sauce. Ketchup, herbed mayo, and garlic aioli are some tasty options.

methods.name: Whipping Up Baked Parmesan Carrot Fries

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and line a baking sheet.
steps.description: Set the oven’s temperature to 400 degrees Fahrenheit (200 degrees Celsius) and allow it to fully heat. Next, line a large baking sheet with parchment paper to keep the fries from sticking. You can substitute a silicone baking mat for the parchment paper if you prefer.

steps.headline: Cut the carrots.
steps.description: To make the fries, you’ll need 2 large carrots. Use a sharp knife to cut the carrots into long sticks approximately ½-inch (13-mm) thick. You can peel the carrots with a vegetable peeler if you like, but it isn’t necessary.

steps.headline: Combine the egg and water.
steps.description: Add 1 egg and 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of water to a small shallow dish. Use a fork to whisk the two together until they’re fully combined.

steps.headline: Add the parmesan cheese to a shallow dish.
steps.description: Set a second shallow bowl beside the egg wash. Fill it with 6 tablespoons (30 g) of grated Parmesan cheese, spread out in a single layer. You can substitute another hard, grated cheese for the Parmesan, such as Romano or Asiago. If you like, you can season the Parmesan cheese. Garlic powder, dried basil, dried oregano, and/or Italian seasoning are good options.

steps.headline: Dip the carrot fries into the egg mixture and then into the cheese.
steps.description: To coat the fries, dunk the carrot sticks into the egg mixture. Next, roll them in the Parmesan cheese so they’re evenly coated. When you’re dipping the carrot fries into the egg wash, be sure to allow the excess to drip back into the bowl so clumps don’t form when you coat them with the cheese.

steps.headline: Place the fries on the baking sheet and season them with salt and pepper.
steps.description: After you’ve coated the fries, transfer them to the lined baking sheet. Sprinkle them with salt and black pepper to taste. Make sure that the carrot fries are spread out in a single layer on the baking sheet.

steps.headline: Bake the fries in the oven until they are golden brown.
steps.description: Place the baking sheet in the preheated oven. Allow the carrot fries to bake until they are golden brown, which should take 15 to 20 minutes. Turn the fries over halfway through the cooking time to ensure that they cook evenly on both sides.

steps.headline: Combine the mayonnaise and chili sauce.
steps.description: To make the dipping sauce, add 6 tablespoons (90 g) of mayonnaise and 2 tablespoons (34 g) of chili sauce to a small bowl. Mix the two together so they are completely blended. You can use either hot or sweet chili sauce for the fry’s dipping sauce depending on your preference.

steps.headline: Place the fries on a plate and sprinkle with parsley.
steps.description: When the carrot fries are finished baking, transfer them to a plate or platter. Sprinkle them with fresh, chopped parsley. You can omit the parsley if you prefer.

steps.headline: Serve the fries with the chilli mayonnaise dip.
steps.description: Once the carrots are seasoned and garnished with the parsley, place the bowl with the chili mayonnaise dip beside the fries. Serve the dish while the carrot fries are still warm. If you aren’t a fan of the chili mayonnaise dip, you can substitute your favorite dipping sauce. A garlic aioli works well with the Parmesan carrot fries.

text: Frying Up Classic Carrot Fries Heat the oil until it reaches the right temperature. Add 5 cups (1 l) of vegetable oil to a heavy-bottomed saucepan. Place a deep frying temperature in the pan, and heat the oil over medium heat until the temperature reaches 350 degrees Fahrenheit (177 degrees Celsius). If you don’t have a deep frying temperature, a candy thermometer will also work to monitor the oil’s temperature. If you don’t have a thermometer that can withstand high temperatures, toss a small cube of bread into the oil. The oil is hot enough if the bread browns in 3 minutes. Be careful around the hot oil. It can bubble and splatter if it gets too hot. Place the egg whites and breadcrumbs in side by side bowls. Add 6 large, beaten egg whites to a medium bowl. Set a second medium bowl beside it, and fill it with 3 cups (270 g) of panko breadcrumbs. You can substitute regular bread crumbs for the panko if you prefer. Dip the carrot sticks in the egg and toss them in the breadcrumbs. For the fries, you’ll need 4 large carrots that have been peeled and cut into 3-inch (8-cm) long by ½-inch (13-mm) thick sticks. Coat the sticks with the egg whites and then dip them in the breadcrumbs until they are completely covered. After you dip the carrot sticks in the egg whites, make sure to allow the excess to drip back into the bowl. Have a plate or cookie sheet lined with parchment paper ready so you place the carrot fries on it before you fry them. Fry the carrot fries until they are a deep brown. Once the fries are coated with the breadcrumbs, add them to the hot oil in batches. Allow the carrots to fry until they become a deep brown color, which should take 3 to 4 minutes. Use a wooden spoon to move the fries around as they’re frying to ensure that they cook evenly and don’t wind up stuck together. Drain the fries on a paper towel-lined plate. When the fries are finished frying, use a slotted spoons to carefully remove them from the oil. Place them on a plate that’s lined with paper towel to absorb the excess oil. Sprinkle the fries with salt and pepper and serve. To plate the carrot fries, transfer them to a platter. Add some salt and pepper to taste and serve. You can serve the carrot fries with your favorite fry dipping sauce, but because the carrots are sweet, you may prefer to serve them with a spicy or tart dip, such as a chipotle ketchup or lemon yogurt dip. To ensure that the oven is hot enough to roast the carrot fries, set the temperature to 450 degrees Fahrenheit (230 degrees Celsius) and allow it to heat fully. Next, use canola oil to lightly grease a large baking sheet. You can substitute olive or vegetable oil for the canola oil. Peel and cut the carrots. For the fries, you’ll need 1 pound (454 g) of fresh carrots. Use a vegetable peeler to remove the skin and then slice the carrots into ½-inch (13-mm) sticks with a sharp knife. You can cut the carrots into fries in any size that you like, but be aware that you may need to adjust the cooking time. Fries that are thicker than ½-inch (13-mm) will need to cook longer, while fries that are thinner will likely require less cooking time. Toss the carrot fries with the oil and salt. Place the carrot sticks into a large bowl. Add 2 teaspoons (10 ml) of olive oil and ½ teaspoon (3 g) of kosher salt, and mix the carrots well to ensure that they’re evenly seasoned. You can add any other seasonings that you like to the fries. Black pepper, cayenne pepper, garlic powder, chili powder, and paprika are all tasty options. Transfer the fries to the baking sheet and bake until crispy. Once the carrot fries are properly seasoned, place them on the greased baking sheet in a single layer. Set them in the oven, and allow them to cook for 10 to 12 minutes, or until they are as crisp as you’d like. The carrot fries should be crisp on the outside but still tender on the inside just like traditional potato fries. Serve the fries while still warm. When the fries are finished cooking, remove the baking sheet from the oven. Transfer them to a plate or platter, and serve while they are still warm. While the carrot fries are delicious on their own, you can also serve them with a dipping sauce. Ketchup, herbed mayo, and garlic aioli are some tasty options. Whipping Up Baked Parmesan Carrot Fries Preheat the oven and line a baking sheet. Set the oven’s temperature to 400 degrees Fahrenheit (200 degrees Celsius) and allow it to fully heat. Next, line a large baking sheet with parchment paper to keep the fries from sticking. You can substitute a silicone baking mat for the parchment paper if you prefer. Cut the carrots. To make the fries, you’ll need 2 large carrots. Use a sharp knife to cut the carrots into long sticks approximately ½-inch (13-mm) thick. You can peel the carrots with a vegetable peeler if you like, but it isn’t necessary. Combine the egg and water. Add 1 egg and 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of water to a small shallow dish. Use a fork to whisk the two together until they’re fully combined. Add the parmesan cheese to a shallow dish. Set a second shallow bowl beside the egg wash. Fill it with 6 tablespoons (30 g) of grated Parmesan cheese, spread out in a single layer. You can substitute another hard, grated cheese for the Parmesan, such as Romano or Asiago. If you like, you can season the Parmesan cheese. Garlic powder, dried basil, dried oregano, and/or Italian seasoning are good options. Dip the carrot fries into the egg mixture and then into the cheese. To coat the fries, dunk the carrot sticks into the egg mixture. Next, roll them in the Parmesan cheese so they’re evenly coated. When you’re dipping the carrot fries into the egg wash, be sure to allow the excess to drip back into the bowl so clumps don’t form when you coat them with the cheese. Place the fries on the baking sheet and season them with salt and pepper. After you’ve coated the fries, transfer them to the lined baking sheet. Sprinkle them with salt and black pepper to taste. Make sure that the carrot fries are spread out in a single layer on the baking sheet. Bake the fries in the oven until they are golden brown. Place the baking sheet in the preheated oven. Allow the carrot fries to bake until they are golden brown, which should take 15 to 20 minutes. Turn the fries over halfway through the cooking time to ensure that they cook evenly on both sides. Combine the mayonnaise and chili sauce. To make the dipping sauce, add 6 tablespoons (90 g) of mayonnaise and 2 tablespoons (34 g) of chili sauce to a small bowl. Mix the two together so they are completely blended. You can use either hot or sweet chili sauce for the fry’s dipping sauce depending on your preference. Place the fries on a plate and sprinkle with parsley. When the carrot fries are finished baking, transfer them to a plate or platter. Sprinkle them with fresh, chopped parsley. You can omit the parsley if you prefer. Serve the fries with the chilli mayonnaise dip. Once the carrots are seasoned and garnished with the parsley, place the bowl with the chili mayonnaise dip beside the fries. Serve the dish while the carrot fries are still warm. If you aren’t a fan of the chili mayonnaise dip, you can substitute your favorite dipping sauce. A garlic aioli works well with the Parmesan carrot fries.
sentences: Frying Up Classic Carrot Fries Heat the oil until it reaches the right temperature.
Add 5 cups (1 l) of vegetable oil to a heavy-bottomed saucepan.
Place a deep frying temperature in the pan, and heat the oil over medium heat until the temperature reaches 350 degrees Fahrenheit (177 degrees Celsius).
If you don’t have a deep frying temperature, a candy thermometer will also work to monitor the oil’s temperature.
If you don’t have a thermometer that can withstand high temperatures, toss a small cube of bread into the oil.
The oil is hot enough if the bread browns in 3 minutes.
Be careful around the hot oil.
It can bubble and splatter if it gets too hot.
Place the egg whites and breadcrumbs in side by side bowls.
Add 6 large, beaten egg whites to a medium bowl.
Set a second medium bowl beside it, and fill it with 3 cups (270 g) of panko breadcrumbs.
You can substitute regular bread crumbs for the panko if you prefer.
Dip the carrot sticks in the egg and toss them in the breadcrumbs.
For the fries, you’ll need 4 large carrots that have been peeled and cut into 3-inch (8-cm) long by ½-inch (13-mm) thick sticks.
Coat the sticks with the egg whites and then dip them in the breadcrumbs until they are completely covered.
After you dip the carrot sticks in the egg whites, make sure to allow the excess to drip back into the bowl.
Have a plate or cookie sheet lined with parchment paper ready so you place the carrot fries on it before you fry them.
Fry the carrot fries until they are a deep brown.
Once the fries are coated with the breadcrumbs, add them to the hot oil in batches.
Allow the carrots to fry until they become a deep brown color, which should take 3 to 4 minutes.
Use a wooden spoon to move the fries around as they’re frying to ensure that they cook evenly and don’t wind up stuck together.
Drain the fries on a paper towel-lined plate.
When the fries are finished frying, use a slotted spoons to carefully remove them from the oil.
Place them on a plate that’s lined with paper towel to absorb the excess oil.
Sprinkle the fries with salt and pepper and serve.
To plate the carrot fries, transfer them to a platter.
Add some salt and pepper to taste and serve.

You can serve the carrot fries with your favorite fry dipping sauce, but because the carrots are sweet, you may prefer to serve them with a spicy or tart dip, such as a chipotle ketchup or lemon yogurt dip.
Preparing Simple Oven Baked Carrot Fries Preheat the oven and grease a baking sheet.
To ensure that the oven is hot enough to roast the carrot fries, set the temperature to 450 degrees Fahrenheit (230 degrees Celsius) and allow it to heat fully.
Next, use canola oil to lightly grease a large baking sheet.
You can substitute olive or vegetable oil for the canola oil.
Peel and cut the carrots.
For the fries, you’ll need 1 pound (454 g) of fresh carrots.
Use a vegetable peeler to remove the skin and then slice the carrots into ½-inch (13-mm) sticks with a sharp knife.
You can cut the carrots into fries in any size that you like, but be aware that you may need to adjust the cooking time.
Fries that are thicker than ½-inch (13-mm) will need to cook longer, while fries that are thinner will likely require less cooking time.
Toss the carrot fries with the oil and salt.
Place the carrot sticks into a large bowl.
Add 2 teaspoons (10 ml) of olive oil and ½ teaspoon (3 g) of kosher salt, and mix the carrots well to ensure that they’re evenly seasoned.
You can add any other seasonings that you like to the fries.
Black pepper, cayenne pepper, garlic powder, chili powder, and paprika are all tasty options.
Transfer the fries to the baking sheet and bake until crispy.
Once the carrot fries are properly seasoned, place them on the greased baking sheet in a single layer.
Set them in the oven, and allow them to cook for 10 to 12 minutes, or until they are as crisp as you’d like.
The carrot fries should be crisp on the outside but still tender on the inside just like traditional potato fries.
Serve the fries while still warm.
When the fries are finished cooking, remove the baking sheet from the oven.
Transfer them to a plate or platter, and serve while they are still warm.
While the carrot fries are delicious on their own, you can also serve them with a dipping sauce.
Ketchup, herbed mayo, and garlic aioli are some tasty options.
Whipping Up Baked Parmesan Carrot Fries Preheat the oven and line a baking sheet.
Set the oven’s temperature to 400 degrees Fahrenheit (200 degrees Celsius) and allow it to fully heat.
Next, line a large baking sheet with parchment paper to keep the fries from sticking.
You can substitute a silicone baking mat for the parchment paper if you prefer.
Cut the carrots.
To make the fries, you’ll need 2 large carrots.
Use a sharp knife to cut the carrots into long sticks approximately ½-inch (13-mm) thick.
You can peel the carrots with a vegetable peeler if you like, but it isn’t necessary.
Combine the egg and water.
Add 1 egg and 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of water to a small shallow dish.
Use a fork to whisk the two together until they’re fully combined.
Add the parmesan cheese to a shallow dish.
Set a second shallow bowl beside the egg wash.
Fill it with 6 tablespoons (30 g) of grated Parmesan cheese, spread out in a single layer.
You can substitute another hard, grated cheese for the Parmesan, such as Romano or Asiago.
If you like, you can season the Parmesan cheese.
Garlic powder, dried basil, dried oregano, and/or Italian seasoning are good options.
Dip the carrot fries into the egg mixture and then into the cheese.
To coat the fries, dunk the carrot sticks into the egg mixture.
Next, roll them in the Parmesan cheese so they’re evenly coated.
When you’re dipping the carrot fries into the egg wash, be sure to allow the excess to drip back into the bowl so clumps don’t form when you coat them with the cheese.
Place the fries on the baking sheet and season them with salt and pepper.
After you’ve coated the fries, transfer them to the lined baking sheet.
Sprinkle them with salt and black pepper to taste.
Make sure that the carrot fries are spread out in a single layer on the baking sheet.
Bake the fries in the oven until they are golden brown.
Place the baking sheet in the preheated oven.
Allow the carrot fries to bake until they are golden brown, which should take 15 to 20 minutes.
Turn the fries over halfway through the cooking time to ensure that they cook evenly on both sides.
Combine the mayonnaise and chili sauce.
To make the dipping sauce, add 6 tablespoons (90 g) of mayonnaise and 2 tablespoons (34 g) of chili sauce to a small bowl.
Mix the two together so they are completely blended.
You can use either hot or sweet chili sauce for the fry’s dipping sauce depending on your preference.
Place the fries on a plate and sprinkle with parsley.
When the carrot fries are finished baking, transfer them to a plate or platter.
Sprinkle them with fresh, chopped parsley.
You can omit the parsley if you prefer.
Serve the fries with the chilli mayonnaise dip.
Once the carrots are seasoned and garnished with the parsley, place the bowl with the chili mayonnaise dip beside the fries.
Serve the dish while the carrot fries are still warm.
If you aren’t a fan of the chili mayonnaise dip, you can substitute your favorite dipping sauce.
A garlic aioli works well with the Parmesan carrot fries.
